revision.comment: removed link which only led to the page for Season 9, not the episode itself
revision.text:
{{Infobox television episode | Title = Going, Going, Gone | Series = [[Grey's Anatomy]] | Image = [[File:Grey's Anatomy season 9 premiere.png|250px]] | Caption = The episode honored Mark Sloan with a title card of his lifespan. | Season = 9 | Episode = 1 | Length = 43 minutes | Airdate = {{start date|2012|9|27}} | Guests = *[[Jason George]] as Dr. Ben Warren *[[William Daniels]] as Dr. Craig Thomas *[[Steven Culp]] as Dr. Parker *[[Philip Casnoff]] as Dr. Mel Barnett *[[Gaius Charles]] as Dr. Shane Ross *[[Camilla Luddington]] as Dr. Jo Wilson *[[Tina Majorino]] as Dr. Heather Brookes *[[Jerrika Hinton]] as Dr. Stephanie Edwards | Writer = Stacy McKee | Director = [[Rob Corn]] | Music = "Body of Work"
"My Heart Goes Boom Boom"
"My Oh My"
"Feels Like the End"
"Portions for Foxes"
"Without You"
"Into You" | Episode list = [[Grey's Anatomy (season 9)|''Grey's Anatomy'' (season 9)]]
[[List of Grey's Anatomy episodes|List of ''Grey's Anatomy'' episodes]] | Prev = [[Flight (Grey's Anatomy)|Flight]] | Next = Remember the Time }} "'''Going, Going, Gone'''" is the first episode of the [[Grey's Anatomy (season 9)|ninth season]] of the American television [[medical drama]] ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'', and the show's 173rd episode overall. Written by Stacy McKee and directed by [[Rob Corn]], the episode was originally broadcast on the [[American Broadcasting Company]] (ABC) in the United States on September 27, 2012. The initial airing was viewed by 11.73 million people and garnered a 4.4 [[Nielsen ratings#Ratings/share and total viewers|Nielsen rating]] in the 18–49 demographic, registering the show as the week's highest rated television drama. ''Grey's Anatomy'' centers around a group of physicians struggling to balance their professional lives with their personal lives. In this episode, the doctors of Seattle Grace Mercy West Hospital cope with the physical and emotional reverberations of the aviation accident that took place in the [[Flight (Grey's Anatomy)|season eight finale]], while several [[Residency (medicine)|surgical residents]] are promoted. Further storylines include [[Dr. Cristina Yang]] ([[Sandra Oh]]) relocating to a different hospital, and a group of new [[Internship (medicine)|interns]] being intimidated by [[Dr. Meredith Grey]] ([[Ellen Pompeo]]). The episode saw the death of [[Mark Sloan (Grey's Anatomy)|Dr. Mark Sloan]] ([[Eric Dane]]); the actor was let go due to budget cuts by the producers. Excessive spoilers were not released, in order to keep the fates of select characters unknown. However, multiple cast members leaked pictures from the set. [[Jason George]] returned in guest capacity, along with newcomers [[William Daniels]], [[Steven Culp]], [[Philip Casnoff]], [[Gaius Charles]], [[Camilla Luddington]], [[Tina Majorino]], and [[Jerrika Hinton]]. Critics generally regarded "Going, Going, Gone" as disconsolate. ==Plot== In the [[Flight (Grey's Anatomy)|season eight finale]], [[Dr. Meredith Grey]] ([[Ellen Pompeo]]), [[Dr. Derek Shepherd]] ([[Patrick Dempsey]]), [[Dr. Cristina Yang]] ([[Sandra Oh]]), [[Dr. Lexie Grey]] ([[Chyler Leigh]]), [[Mark Sloan (Grey's Anatomy)|Dr. Mark Sloan]] ([[Eric Dane]]), and [[Arizona Robbins|Dr. Arizona Robbins]] ([[Jessica Capshaw]]) are caught in an aviation accident, leaving Lexie Grey dead, and the rest of the doctors stranded. "Going, Going, Gone" picks up about one month after the crash, and throughout the episode, features home videos of Sloan. The episode begins with Seattle Grace Mercy West Hospital's new [[Internship (medicine)|interns]], Dr. Shane Ross ([[Gaius Charles]]), Dr. Jo Wilson ([[Camilla Luddington]]), Dr. Heather Brookes ([[Tina Majorino]]), and Dr. Stephanie Edwards (Jerrika Hinton), expressing fear of Meredith Grey, who is now an [[Attending physician|attending]] [[general surgery|general surgeon]]. It is revealed that former [[Residency (medicine)|resident]] [[Dr. Alex Karev]] ([[Justin Chambers]]) will be pursuing a [[pediatric surgery|pediatric surgical]] [[Fellowship (medicine)|fellowship]] at [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]]. The scene switches to [[Minnesota]], where Yang is now a [[Cardiothoracic surgery|cardiothoracic surgical]] fellow. Back in [[Seattle]], Dr. Ben Warren ([[Jason George]]) surprises his fiancée [[Dr. Miranda Bailey]] ([[Chandra Wilson]]) with a visit. The couple reunites with constant sexual activity, for which the interns tease Bailey. Meanwhile, [[Dr. Callie Torres]] ([[Sara Ramirez]]) allows Shepherd to operate on a [[spinal cord]], despite his hand being broken from the plane crash. Thereafter, it is revealed that Sloan is in a comatose state, and will be taken off of life support that evening. In the hospital cafeteria, Meredith Grey announces that Wilson will be given the honor of performing a supervised [[appendectomy]], a procedure historically used as a reward for interns. The hospital's chief of surgery, [[Dr. Owen Hunt]] ([[Kevin McKidd]]), introduces the new pediatric surgery attending, Dr. Mel Barnett ([[Philip Casnoff]]), to Torres and Karev. Barnett informs Karev that he will not be continuing with the African orphan charity program (a function to treat ill children from [[Third World]] countries), something that was initially finalized by the latter and former chief of pediatric surgery, Robbins. Karev becomes upset about this, and asks Torres to prevent Barnett from discontinuing the program, though Torres shows no interest in helping Karev. During Shepherd's surgery, his hand becomes numb, and he frustratedly exits the operating room. In the intern appendectomy, Wilson makes a mistake and freezes, leading to a scolding from Meredith Grey. Back in Minnesota, Yang is annoyed by the peppy attitudes of her superiors at [[Mayo Clinic]], Dr. Craig Thomas ([[William Daniels]]) and Dr. Parker ([[Steven Culp]]), so she decides to take a trip to Seattle for Sloan's death. However, her [[Post Traumatic Stress Disorder|PTSD]] hinders her from boarding the plane, and she ultimately remains in Minnesota. Meanwhile, [[Jackson Avery|Dr. Jackson Avery]] ([[Jesse Williams (actor)|Jesse Williams]]), now a [[plastic surgery|plastic surgical]] fellow, sits by Sloan's bedside and talks of medical cases to him. [[Dr. Richard Webber]] ([[James Pickens, Jr.]]) enters Sloan's hospital room and removes him from life support. Unable to cope with Sloan's death, Meredith Grey boards a plane to visit Yang, but panics before it takes off. Shortly thereafter, Meredith Grey finds Karev at the airport bar, where he reveals that he will be staying at Seattle Grace Mercy West Hospital. The next morning, Hunt visits [[April Kepner|Dr. April Kepner]] ([[Sarah Drew]]) at her family's farm, and asks her to begin working in Seattle again. At the conclusion of the episode, Torres returns home to Robbins, who is revealed to have had her lower left leg amputated as a result of the crash. ==Production== [[File:Patrick Dempsey cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Prior to the premiere, [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] asked [[Patrick Dempsey]] ''(pictured)'' to remove a set photo of [[Mark Sloan (Grey's Anatomy)|Mark Sloan]] from [[Twitter]].|alt=Patrick Dempsey smiling, wearing a navy blue suit.]] Running for approximately 43 minutes,{{cite web | url=http://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/greys-anatomy-season-9/id550253486 | title=Grey's Anatomy, Season 9 | publisher=[[Apple, Inc.|Apple]] | work=[[iTunes Store]] | accessdate=September 29, 2012}} the episode was written by Stacy McKee and directed by [[Rob Corn]].{{cite episode | title=Going, Going, Gone | series=[[Grey's Anatomy]] | credits=Writer: McKee, Stacy. Director: Corn, Rob | network=[[American Broadcasting Company]] | airdate=September 27, 2012 | season=[[Grey's Anatomy (season 9)|9]]|episode=1}} The episode featured the songs "Body of Work", "My Heart Goes Boom Boom", "My Oh My", "Feels Like the End", "Portions for Foxes", "Without You", and "Into You".{{cite web | url=http://abc.go.com/music-lounge/show/greys-anatomy/86534 | title=Music from the latest episode: Episode 901: 'Going, Going, Gone' | publisher=American Broadcasting Company | work=Grey's Anatomy | date=September 27, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012}} George returned to the episode as Warren, while Daniels, Culp, Casnoff, Charles, Luddington, Majorino, and Hinton made their first appearances as Thomas, Parker, Barnett, Ross, Wilson, Brookes, and Edwards, respectively.{{cite web | url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/greys-anatomy/cast/191535 | title=Grey's Anatomy Cast and Details | work=[[TV Guide]] | accessdate=September 29, 2012}} The episode's initial script read-through took place on July 16, 2012.{{cite web | url=http://twitter.com/shondarhimes/status/224935692462071809 | title=GA Season 9 Table Read is today! | publisher=[[Twitter]] | date=July 16, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Rhimes, Shonda}} Scenes in the operating room were filmed at the Prospect Studios in [[Los Feliz, Los Angeles|Los Feliz]], [[Los Angeles]].{{cite web|last=Clarendon|first=Dan|title=Where Is Grey's Anatomy Filmed, Anyway?|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/greys-anatomy/articles/where-is-greys-anatomy-filmed-anyway|publisher=The Cambio Network|work=[[Wetpaint]]|accessdate=September 29, 2012|date=December 20, 2010}} While creating the visual of Robbins' amputated leg, the special effects crew digitally removed Capshaw's real leg, and replaced it with a graphically created limb.{{cite web | url=http://tvline.com/2012/09/28/greys-anatomy-arizona-leg-amputated-spoilers/ | title=Grey's Anatomy's Jessica Capshaw on Arizona's Loss and Blaming Callie: 'She's Steamin' Mad' | publisher=[[PMC (company)|PMC]] | work=[[TVLine]] | date=September 28, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Ausiello, Michael}} Prior to broadcast, series creator [[Shonda Rhimes]] did not release much information about the season premiere.{{cite web | url=http://www.wetpaint.com/greys-anatomy/articles/greys-anatomy-update-shonda-rhimes-is-already-working-on-episode | title=Grey's Anatomy Update: Shonda Rhimes Is Already Working on Episode ... | publisher=The Cambio Network | work=Wetpaint | date=September 6, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Martin, Rebecca}} However, it was revealed prior to broadcast that there would be a time jump in the episode.{{cite web | url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Kecks-Exclusives-Ellen-Pompeo-Greys-Season9-1053180.aspx | title=Keck's Exclusives: Ellen Pompeo Talks Grey's Anatomy Season 9 | work=TV Guide | date=September 18, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Keck, William}} After it was announced that Dane would be departing shortly after the commencement of the [[Grey's Anatomy (season 9)|ninth season]],{{cite web | url=http://tvline.com/2012/07/26/grey-anatomy-eric-dane-leaving/ | title=Grey's Anatomy Exclusive: Eric Dane Checks Out! | publisher=PMC | work=TVLine | date=July 26, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Ausiello, Michael}} Dempsey uploaded a set picture on [[Twitter]] of Sloan in bad condition. Due to the unwanted release of spoilers, the [[American Broadcasting Company]] (ABC) requested that he delete the photo, and it was subsequently removed.{{cite web|last=Gonzalez|first=Sandra|title='Grey's Anatomy': Did Patrick Dempsey tweet a huge spoiler?!|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2012/08/01/greys-anatomy-eric-dane-patrick-dempsey-spoiler/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|accessdate=September 29, 2012|date=August 1, 2012}} The cast and crew of ''Grey's Anatomy'' were being particularly quiet about the fate of Capshaw's character.{{cite web|last=Dowling|first=Christina|title=Grey's Anatomy Cheat Sheet: What We Know and What Lies Ahead|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/341115/grey-s-anatomy-cheat-sheet-what-we-know-and-what-lies-ahead|work=[[E! Online]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=September 29, 2012|date=September 12, 2012}} This secrecy was compromised when McKidd posted a picture on his Twitter account of the editing room, in which there was a picture of Robbins alive on the screen. The picture has since been taken down.{{cite web|last=Martin|first=Rebecca|title=Grey's Anatomy Season 9 Spoiler Photo: Is Arizona Alive?|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/greys-anatomy/articles/greys-anatomy-season-9-spoiler-photo-is-arizona-alive|work=Wetpaint|publisher=The Cambio Network|accessdate=September 29, 2012|date=September 12, 2012}} Discussing Robbins' storyline in "Going, Going, Gone", Capshaw revealed that she was "shocked" when it was made known to her that the character's leg would be amputated.{{cite web | url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Greys-Anatomy-Jessica-Capshaw-Spoilers-Season9-1053937.aspx | title=Grey's Anatomy Scoop: Jessica Capshaw Discusses Arizona's Fate and What's Next | work=TV Guide | date=September 28, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Abrams, Natalie}} The actress additionally noted that it was difficult to keep the fate of her character a secret. Following the premiere, ''[[E! Online]]'' reported that Dane's death and departure in the premiere were results of budgetary cuts, mandated by ABC.{{cite web | url=http://www.eonline.com/news/349596/grey-s-anatomy-why-did-spoiler-alert-have-to-die-insiders-spill-scoop | title=Grey's Anatomy: Why Did (Spoiler Alert) Have to Die? Insiders Spill Scoop | publisher=NBCUniversal | work=E! Online | date=September 27, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=dos Santos, Kristin}} Speaking of Sloan's death, Rhimes said it was the "most tragic", adding that "he's part of the fabric of the show".{{cite web | url=http://www.shondaland.com/photos/230249 | title=Why the F#%k Does Shonda Kill Characters?! | publisher=[[Shondaland]] | date=September 28, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Rhimes, Shonda}} Rhimes wrote that anything other than the character dying would entail him leaving his daughter behind, something the writers did not want. However, she noted that the writing team considered having him move to Los Angeles to be with [[Dr. Addison Montgomery]] ([[Kate Walsh (actress)|Kate Walsh]]) after her departure from ''[[Private Practice (TV series)|Private Practice]]'', but they feared it would have given the impression that his love confession for Lexie Grey was forgotten. ==Reception== ===Broadcast and ratings=== "Going, Going, Gone" was originally broadcast on Thursday, September 27, 2012 in the United States on ABC. The episode's total viewership of 11.73 million ranked the show second in its 9:00 [[Eastern Standard Time (North America)|EST]] time slot, trailing [[CBS]]'s ''[[Person of Interest (TV series)|Person of Interest]]'' (14.28 million), and fifth for the night, behind CBS's ''[[Two and a Half Men]]'' (12.54 million), ''[[Elementary (TV series)|Elementary]]'' (13.41 million), and ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'' (15.66 million). The installment's 4.4 [[Nielsen ratings#Ratings/share and total viewers|Nielsen rating]] in the target 18–49 demographic ranked the series first in its time slot and second for the night, trailing only CBS's ''The Big Bang Theory'' (5.0).{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/09/28/thursday-final-ratings-big-bang-theory-greys-anatomy-adjusted-up-parks-rec-up-all-night-snl-weekend-update-the-office-glee-scandal-rock-center-adjust/150556/|title=Thursday Final Ratings: 'Big Bang Theory', 'Grey's Anatomy', Adjusted Up; 'Parks & Rec', 'Up All Night', 'SNL: Weekend Update', 'The Office', 'Glee', 'Scandal', 'Rock Center' Adjusted Down|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|work=[[TV by the Numbers]]|publisher=[[Zap2it]]|date=September 28, 2012|accessdate=September 29, 2012}} In the key 18–34 demographic, the episode earned a 3.9 Nielsen rating, qualifying ''Grey's Anatomy'' as the top television program of the night in that demographic.{{cite web | url=http://abcmedianet.com/Web/dnr/dispDNR.aspx?id=100212_04 | title=Airing 5 of the Top 20 TV Shows, ABC Claims Premiere Week's No. 1 Comedy, No. 1 Drama and No. 1 New Comedy | publisher=American Broadcasting Company | work=Medianet | date=October 2, 2012 | accessdate=April 23, 2013 | author=Lindsey, Jeff}} "Going, Going, Gone"'s total viewership and 18–49 rating tallied the show's highest numbers since "[[Suddenly (Grey's Anatomy)|Suddenly]]" on Thursday, January 5, 2012 (4.5 18–49 rating, 12.12 million viewers).{{cite web | url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/01/06/thursday-final-ratings-the-vampire-diaries-adjusted-up/115573/ | title=Thursday Final Ratings: 'The Vampire Diaries' Adjusted Up; 'Wipeout,' 'Private Practice' Adjusted Down | publisher=Zap2it | work=TV by the Numbers | date=January 6, 2012 | accessdate=December 16, 2012 | author=Gorman, Bill}} The 11.73 million people tuned into the episode marked a 3 percent viewership increase from the season eight finale (11.44 million),{{cite web|last=Bibel|first=Sara|title=Thursday Final Ratings: 'American Idol', 'Grey's Anatomy', '30 Rock' Adjusted Up; 'Touch', 'Scandal' Adjusted Down|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/05/18/thursday-final-ratings-american-idol-greys-anatomy-30-rock-adjusted-up-touch-scandal-adjusted-down/134984/|work=TV by the Numbers|publisher=Zap2it|accessdate=December 16, 2012|date=May 18, 2012}} and a 13 percent increase from the [[Free Falling (Grey's Anatomy)|previous season premiere]] (10.38 million). The episode's 4.4 Nielsen rating in the 18–49 demographic was a 7 percent increase from the season eight finale and previous season premiere, which both received 4.1 18–49 ratings. The Nielsen score additionally registered the show as the week's highest rated drama and third-highest rated scripted series in the 18–49 demographic, placing behind CBS's ''The Big Bang Theory'' (5.0) and ABC's ''[[Modern Family]]'' (5.5).{{cite web | url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/10/02/tv-ratings-broadcast-top-25-sunday-night-football-tops-week-1-viewing-among-adults-18-49-and-with-total-viewers/151011/ | title=TV Ratings Broadcast Top 25: Sunday Night Football Tops Week 1 Viewing Among Adults 18–49 and With Total Viewers | publisher=Zap2it | work=TV by the Numbers | date=October 2, 2012 | accessdate=October 2, 2012 | author=Bibel, Sara}} Seven days of [[Time shifting|time-shifted viewing]] added on an additional 1.5 rating points in the 18–49 demographic and 3.28 million viewers, bringing the total viewership for the episode to 15.01 million viewers with a 5.9 Nielsen rating in the 18–49 demographic.{{cite web | url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/10/14/live7-dvr-ratings-revolution-leads-absolute-gains-grimm-leads-percentage-gains-in-premiere-week-week-1/152888/ | title=Live+7 DVR Ratings: 'Revolution' Leads Adults 18-49 Ratings and Viewership Gains; 'Grimm' Leads Percentage Gains in Premiere Week (Week 1) | publisher=Zap2it | work=TV by the Numbers | date=October 14, 2012 | accessdate=December 16, 2012 | author=Seidman, Robert}} ===Critical reviews=== [[File:Eric Dane March 2015.jpg|upright|thumb|left|150px| [[Eric Dane]] received praise for his portrayal of [[Mark Sloan (Grey's Anatomy)|Mark Sloan]].]] {{Quote box|align=right|width=25em|quote="The videos so well helped to illustrate what a great guy Sloan ultimately was, because it seems that people mostly just remember all his skirt-chasing and general pig-headedness. The fact is that last night's episode was celebrating a great man, who was a father, a mentor, a friend, and a great doctor."|source=— Tanner Stransky, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{cite web | url=http://tvrecaps.ew.com/recap/greys-anatomy-season-9-episode-1/ | title='Grey's Anatomy' recap: Life Support | publisher=Time Inc | work=Entertainment Weekly | date=September 28, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Stransky, Tanner}}}} The majority of critics concluded that the episode was disconsolate. ''E! Online''{{'s}} [[Kristin dos Santos]] called the installment "gut-wrenching", saying it was the type of episode that "rips out your heart and feeds it to you with a spoon". Ann Oldenburg of ''[[USA Today]]'' summarized that the episode required viewers to "reach for the [[Kleenex]]".{{cite web|last=Oldenburg|first=Ann|title='Grey's Anatomy' premiere: 'Going, going, gone'|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/2012/09/28/greys-anatomy-premiere-going-going-gone/1599609/|work=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|accessdate=September 30, 2012|date=September 28, 2012}} ''[[TV Guide]]''{{'s}} Natalie Abrams called the episode "heartbreaking", and praised the performances by Dempsey and Ramirez for their realism.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/greys-anatomy/episode-1-season-9/191535|title=Grey's Anatomy Recap: 'Going, Going, Gone' Season 9, Episode 1|work=TV Guide|date=September 27, 2012|accessdate=September 30, 2012|author=Abrams, Natalie}} Writing for ''[[Newsday]]'', Verne Gay called Sloan's death scene "touching", and opined that the show will be different without the character's presence.{{cite web | url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/tv-zone-1.811968/r-i-p-to-grey-s-mcsteamy-1.4051093 | title=R.I.P to 'Grey's' McSteamy | publisher=[[Cablevision]] | work=[[Newsday]] | date=September 28, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Gay, Verne}} Kelly Schremph of [[Hollywood.com]] said the installment was "emotionally exhausting", adding that it foreshadowed a "drama-packed season".{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywood.com/content/news_detail.aspx?id=41129749&p=1 | title='Grey's Anatomy' Recap: The Plane Crash Claims Another Victim | publisher=[[Hollywood.com]] | date=September 28, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Schremph, Kelly}} Schremph commented that all of the changes made it feel like an alternative reality episode, such as was featured in season eight. Writing for ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', Tanner Stransky expressed similar viewpoints with Schremph, commenting that the installment paved the way for a great season, and that it resembled season eight's alternative reality episode. Stransky appreciated the "dignity" provided in Sloan's death scene, noting that the song played during the scene was "killer" and "so fitting". Jason Hughes of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' called Sloan's death day "fateful".{{cite web|last=Hughes|first=Jason|title='Grey's Anatomy' Premiere: The Plane Crash Claims One More Victim|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/28/greys-anatomy-who-dies-video_n_1921855.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|publisher=[[AOL|AOL, Inc]]|accessdate=September 29, 2012|date=September 28, 2012}} ''TV Fanatic'' gave a largely positive review to the season, "Grey's Anatomy always knows how to bring the drama and they did not fail in the Season 9 Premiere."http://www.tvfanatic.com/2012/09/greys-anatomy-review-everything-changes/ The ''[[International Business Times]]''{{'}} Arlene Paredes concluded that the episode "raised the bar for deeply emotional yet again", and noted that it was "one of the most high-anticipated TV [returns] this fall".{{cite web|last=Paredes|first=Arlene|title=Grey's Anatomy Season 9 Premiere Review: 'Going, going, gone'|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/388964/20120928/greys-anatomy-season-9-premiere-recap.htm#.UGe_VEIxXCD|work=[[International Business Times]]|publisher=[[Etienne Uzac]]|accessdate=September 29, 2012|date=September 28, 2012}} ''[[TVLine]]''{{'s}} [[Michael Ausiello]] opined that the attempt to hide Robbins' fate was the "worst kept secret in TV land".{{cite web | url=http://tvline.com/2012/09/27/greys-anatomy-season-9-episode-1-recap/ | title=Grey's Anatomy Premiere Recap: Going, Going... Gulp – Were You Surprised By the Big Twist? | publisher=PMC | work=TVLine | date=September 27, 2012 | accessdate=September 29, 2012 | author=Ausiello, Michael}} Writing for ''[[AfterEllen]]'', Bridget McManus threatened to boycott the show if Capshaw's character was killed, but thought the [[FaceTime]] calls between Yang and Meredith Grey were humorous.{{cite web|last=McManus|first=Bridget|title='Grey's Anatomy' recap: 'Going, Going, Gone' (9.1)|url=http://www.afterellen.com/content/2012/09/greys-anatomy-recap-going-going-gone-91|work=[[AfterEllen]]|publisher=[[Logo (TV channel)|Logo]]|accessdate=September 29, 2012|date=September 28, 2012}} Mark A. Perigard of the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' was critical of the time it took to rescue the doctors, and deemed the flashbacks featuring Sloan "unconvincing".{{cite web|last=Perigard|first=Mark A.|title='Grey’s Anatomy': We all leave bits behind!|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/blogs/entertainment/love_that_tv/?p=1265&srvc=blogs&position=recent_bullet|work=[[Boston Herald]]|publisher=Herald Media Inc|accessdate=September 30, 2012|date=September 28, 2012}} ''[[Zap2it]]''{{'s}} Carina Adly MacKenzie opined that it "became increasingly clear" that Sloan would die as the episode progressed, and praised Capshaw's performance, noting that it was "brief but truly striking".{{cite web | url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2012/09/greys-anatomy-says-goodbye-in-going-going-gone-eric-dane-and-jessica-capshaws-new-twists-revealed.html | title='Grey's Anatomy' says goodbye in 'Going, Going, Gone': Eric Dane and Jessica Capshaw's twists revealed | publisher=[[Tribune Media Services]] | work=Zap2it | date=September 28, 2012 | accessdate=December 16, 2012 | author=MacKenzie, Carina Adly}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{portal|Grey's Anatomy|Television}} *[http://abc.go.com/shows/greys-anatomy/episode-detail/going-going-gone/1017496 "Going, Going, Gone"] at [[ABC.com]] *{{IMDb episode|2397001|Going, Going, Gone}} *[http://www.tv.com/shows/greys-anatomy/going-going-gone-2545956/ "Going, Going, Gone"] at [[TV.com]] {{Grey's Anatomy episodes|9}} {{Grey's Anatomy}} {{good article}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Going, Going, Gone (''Grey's Anatomy'')}} [[Category:2012 television episodes]] [[Category:Grey's Anatomy episodes]]
